message: Participants receive lifetime access to 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with direct feedback, 100 coding assignments and practice questions, the entire source code of a working production system, access to a private community, direct access to the instructor, lifetime access to past and future cohorts, and a program certificate upon completion.
Yes, the live sessions of the program are recorded.

The cost to join the program is $500, and it includes lifetime access to 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with direct feedback, 100 coding assignments and practice questions, access to the source code of a working production system, a private community, direct access to the instructor, a program certificate upon completion, and lifetime access to every past and future cohort.
Answer: The cost of joining the program is $500, which is a one-time payment that gives you lifetime access with no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs.

'Lifetime access' in the context of the program means that once you pay to join the program, you will have immediate access to every past, present, and future cohort. You only need to pay once and can participate in as many iterations of the program as you'd like without any additional costs.

The program's live sessions for building machine learning systems include discussions on the first principles behind building machine learning systems, step-by-step coding instructions, and opportunities to ask questions and interact with the instructor and other students in real-time.

To enroll in the program, one must pay a one-time fee of $500. There are no monthly fees, annual fees, or hidden costs. Once the fee is paid, the participant gets lifetime access to the program, including past and future cohorts, without any additional financial obligations.

- 18 hours of live, interactive sessions
- 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions
- A final project with direct feedback
- 100 coding assignments and practice questions
- Entire source code of a working production system
- Private community collaboration
- Direct access to the instructor
- Lifetime access to past and future cohorts
- Program certificate upon completion

Unique or exclusive materials:
- The entire source code of a working production system
- Direct feedback on the final project

The practical skills you will acquire from the program include designing and writing code to build an end-to-end machine learning system from scratch, learning best practices to tackle significant challenges faced by machine learning engineers in building, evaluating, running, monitoring, and maintaining machine learning systems in real-world scenarios.

The upcoming Cohort 17 of the program will start on February 3, 2025, and end on February 20, 2025. The weekly schedule for Cohort 17 is as follows:
- Live sessions every Monday and Thursday at 10:00 AM EST
- Individual work on Tuesday and Friday
- Optional office hours on Wednesday

Please note that the live sessions will be 2 hours long on both Monday and Thursday.
The copyright for the materials made available is registered under Tideily LLC. The specific rights reserved are not mentioned, but the contact email provided is svpino@gmail.com.

The main subjects discussed in Session 1 of the program include:
- The difference between production machine learning and traditional machine learning approaches.
- Strategies to solve the right problem with the right solution.
- Critical questions to ask before starting any project.
- Techniques for problem framing, inversion, and the haystack principle for building successful applications.
- The first rule of machine learning engineering and how to start building.
- Data collection strategies to gather the necessary data for the project.

These topics are focused on helping participants understand the unique challenges and considerations when working on machine learning projects aimed at production deployment.
You can access recordings of the live sessions from the Machine Learning School program if you decide to attend classes asynchronously later using the recording.
Some of the strategies for active learning highlighted in the course are uncertainty sampling and diversity sampling.

The upcoming cohort of the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' program starts on February 3, 2025. The course runs for 3 weeks, with live sessions taking place every Monday and Thursday at 10:00 AM EST, and additional sessions on Wednesdays.

In the context of the program, 'lifetime access' implies that once you pay to join the program, you will have access to every past, present, and future cohort. This means you can participate in as many iterations as you'd like, benefiting from updates and improvements in each new cohort.
Those interested in implementing the concepts discussed in class should set aside 2 to 4 hours weekly to complete the code walkthroughs and work on the assignments.

Participants, including those with disabilities, will gain practical skills in building production-ready machine learning systems from the ground up. They will learn critical problem-solving strategies, data collection techniques, coding instructions, and how to start freelancing on Upwork. Additionally, they will have access to coding assignments, the complete source code of a production system, and direct feedback and support from the community and the instructor.
The strategies covered in the course for active learning include uncertainty and diversity sampling strategies to address selection bias and ensure data diversity.

In Session 2 of the course "Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck" on the Machine Learning School website, the topics covered are data cleaning, feature engineering, turning data into numbers using vectorization techniques, producing homogeneous features, handling missing values, choosing the best model, overfitting, hyperparameter tuning, experiment tracking, and measuring the quality of the holdout set.
The cost structure for joining the program at the Machine Learning School is a one-time payment of $500 for lifetime access to all past and future cohorts.

The program offers a practical, hands-on learning approach for machine learning. Participants are provided with 18 hours of live, interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, a final project with direct feedback, 100 coding assignments and practice questions, the entire source code of a working production system, a private community for collaboration, direct access to the instructor, lifetime access to past and future cohorts, and a program certificate upon completion.

Some key benefits offered by the program include lifetime access, 18 hours of live interactive sessions, 10 hours of step-by-step coding instructions, 100 coding assignments, access to the complete source code of a production system, and the opportunity to start freelancing on Upwork. 

The topics covered in the first session include:
1. What makes production machine learning different
2. Strategies for solving the right problem with the right solution
3. Critical questions to ask before starting a project
4. Problem framing, inversion, and the haystack principle
5. The first rule of machine learning engineering
6. Data collection strategies

The focus of the 'Building Machine Learning Systems That Don't Suck' course is to help participants build production-ready machine learning systems from the ground up. The next cohort is scheduled to start on February 3 - 20, 2025.

The strategies discussed for active learning in the course include uncertainty and diversity sampling. The techniques covered for handling missing values include imputation techniques.

The cost structure for joining the machine learning program is a one-time payment with no monthly or annual fees. The program is designed for technical professionals such as software engineers, data scientists, data analysts, machine learning engineers, technical managers, and anyone interested in using machine learning to solve real-world problems.
